problem: What is the remainder when $129^{34}+96^{38}$ is divided by $11$?
solution:
We use the property that $a \equiv b \pmod{m}$ implies $a^c \equiv b^c \pmod{m}$.

Since $129 \equiv -3 \pmod{11}$ and $96 \equiv -3 \pmod{11}$, we have  $$129^{34}+96^{38} \equiv (-3)^{34}+(-3)^{38} \equiv 3^{34}+3^{38} \pmod{11}.$$Since $3^5 \equiv 1 \pmod{11},$ we can see that $3^{34} = (3^5)^{6} \cdot 3^4$ and $3^{38} = (3^5)^{7} \cdot 3^3.$

Then,  \begin{align*}
129^{34}+96^{38}&\equiv (3^5)^{6} \cdot 3^4 + (3^5)^{7} \cdot 3^3\\
& \equiv 3^4 + 3^3\\
& \equiv 81 + 27\\
& \equiv 108 \\
&\equiv \boxed{9} \pmod{11}.
\end{align*}
model_solution:
Step 1: Apply modular arithmetic properties to simplify the expression $129^{34}+96^{38}$ by finding the remainders of the bases when divided by 11.
$129 \equiv 5\pmod{11}$
$96 \equiv 4\pmod{11}$
Step 2: Use modular arithmetic properties to simplify the expression $129^{34}+96^{38}$ using the equivalent expressions we found in Step 1.
$129^{34}\equiv 5^{34}\pmod{11}$
$96^{38}\equiv 4^{38}\pmod{11}$
Step 3: 
$5^{34} \equiv (5^3)^{11} \cdot 5^1 \equiv 125^{11} \cdot 5 \equiv 3^{11} \cdot 5 \pmod{11}$
$3^{11} \equiv 3 \pmod{11}$
$3^{11} \cdot 5 \equiv 15 \equiv 4 \pmod{11}$
$4^{38} \equiv (4^2)^{19} \equiv 16^{19} \equiv 5^{19} \equiv 5 \pmod{11}$
$129^{34}+96^{38} \equiv 4 + 5 \equiv 9 \pmod{11}$
$129^{34}+96^{38} \equiv 9 \pmod{11}$
Final Answer: $\boxed{9}$
